item.title:
Keep watching the U.S. Dollar:
As the S&P 500 rises +5% in 2 days on ‚Äútariff de-escalation‚Äù headlines, the U.S. Dollar Index, $DXY, is up a mere 0.2% today.
The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.
Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.
It‚Äôs almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.
Something is off. (From TKL)
item.content:
Keep watching the U.S. Dollar:

The U.S. Dollar is just about the only asset not buying these headlines today.

Furthermore, the U.S. Dollar has been a key leading indicator of trade war sentiment.

It‚Äôs almost as though the U.S. Dollar thinks U.S. trade headlines have lost credibility.

item.title:
Retail investors were just cheated:
Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."
These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.
This summit was not open to the public or to the media.
Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."
Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.
The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.
Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.
How is this fair for retail investors? (From TKL)
item.content:
Retail investors were just cheated:

Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."

These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.

This summit was not open to the public or to the media.

Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."

Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.

The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.

Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.

How is this fair for retail investors?
item.contentSnippet:
Retail investors were just cheated:
Yesterday at 12:00 PM ET, US Treasury Secretary Bessent said he sees "de-escalation with China" and the current situation is "unsustainable."
These comments were provided at a CLOSED-DOOR investor summit hosted by JP Morgan.
This summit was not open to the public or to the media.
Then, at 5:18 PM ET, President Trump said tariffs on China "will not be as high as 145%."
Bessent effectively told a closed-group of Wall Street investors that de-escalation with China was coming BEFORE the public knew.
The result was a move of +5% in S&P 500 futures, for a total of +$2.2 TRILLION of market cap.
Investors at the JP Morgan event were able to front-run these headlines.
How is this fair for retail investors?

item.content:
BREAKING: China signals openness to U.S. trade talks but warns against continued threats.

item.contentSnippet:
BREAKING: China signals openness to U.S. trade talks but warns against continued threats.
S&P 500 futures extend gains to +2.5%.

item.title:
CHINA SIGNALS OPENNESS TO U.S. TRADE TALKS, WARNS AGAINST THREATS
China expressed willingness to resume trade talks with the U.S., a day after President Trump suggested cutting tariffs on Chinese goods. However, Beijing warned it won‚Äôt negotiate under continued threats.
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want a trade war, but we‚Äôre not afraid of one,‚Äù said Foreign Ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun. ‚ÄúIf we talk, the door is open.‚Äù
Both sides appear to be softening their stance. Trump said he‚Äôs not playing ‚Äúhardball‚Äù and expects a deal. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent also predicted a de-escalation of tensions.
This shift follows weeks of rising tariffs and sharp rhetoric that rattled global markets. The change in tone has helped fuel a stock market rebound, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 2.4% on Wednesday.
Despite the optimism, a quick resolution seems unlikely. Beijing has been preparing its people for a long-term struggle, and trust between the two governments remains low.
China insists the U.S. must stop threats and show mutual respect for meaningful talks. Meanwhile, President Xi is working to strengthen ties with other countries in the region.
At a meeting with Azerbaijan‚Äôs president, Xi criticized tariffs as harmful to global trade. China also pushed back against U.S. moves in Latin America, accusing Washington of trying to control the Panama Canal. (From Walter Bloomberg)
item.content:
CHINA SIGNALS OPENNESS TO U.S. TRADE TALKS, WARNS AGAINST THREATS

China expressed willingness to resume trade talks with the U.S., a day after President Trump suggested cutting tariffs on Chinese goods. However, Beijing warned it won‚Äôt negotiate under continued threats.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want a trade war, but we‚Äôre not afraid of one,‚Äù said Foreign Ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun. ‚ÄúIf we talk, the door is open.‚Äù

Both sides appear to be softening their stance. Trump said he‚Äôs not playing ‚Äúhardball‚Äù and expects a deal. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent also predicted a de-escalation of tensions.

This shift follows weeks of rising tariffs and sharp rhetoric that rattled global markets. The change in tone has helped fuel a stock market rebound, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 2.4% on Wednesday.

Despite the optimism, a quick resolution seems unlikely. Beijing has been preparing its people for a long-term struggle, and trust between the two governments remains low.

China insists the U.S. must stop threats and show mutual respect for meaningful talks. Meanwhile, President Xi is working to strengthen ties with other countries in the region.

At a meeting with Azerbaijan‚Äôs president, Xi criticized tariffs as harmful to global trade. China also pushed back against U.S. moves in Latin America, accusing Washington of trying to control the Panama Canal.

CHINA SIGNALS OPENNESS TO U.S. TRADE TALKS, WARNS AGAINST THREATS
China expressed willingness to resume trade talks with the U.S., a day after President Trump suggested cutting tariffs on Chinese goods. However, Beijing warned it won‚Äôt negotiate under continued threats.
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want a trade war, but we‚Äôre not afraid of one,‚Äù said Foreign Ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun. ‚ÄúIf we talk, the door is open.‚Äù
Both sides appear to be softening their stance. Trump said he‚Äôs not playing ‚Äúhardball‚Äù and expects a deal. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent also predicted a de-escalation of tensions.
This shift follows weeks of rising tariffs and sharp rhetoric that rattled global markets. The change in tone has helped fuel a stock market rebound, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 2.4% on Wednesday.
Despite the optimism, a quick resolution seems unlikely. Beijing has been preparing its people for a long-term struggle, and trust between the two governments remains low.
China insists the U.S. must stop threats and show mutual respect for meaningful talks. Meanwhile, President Xi is working to strengthen ties with other countries in the region.
At a meeting with Azerbaijan‚Äôs president, Xi criticized tariffs as harmful to global trade. China also pushed back against U.S. moves in Latin America, accusing Washington of trying to control the Panama Canal.

item.content:

Trump is now claiming that tariffs on China will come down from 145%.

item.title:
Something doesn't add up here:
1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"
2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell
3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"
4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell
5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"
6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell
What changed today? (From TKL)
item.content:
Something doesn't add up here:

1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"

2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell

3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"

4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell

5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"

6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell

What changed today?
item.contentSnippet:
Something doesn't add up here:
1. Trump on April 7th: Fed Chair Powell is "slow moving"
2. Bessent on April 14th: Trump Admin is thinking of successor to Powell
3. Trump on April 17th: Fed Chair Powell "will be out of there"
4. Trump on April 19th: "Studying" if he can fire Fed Chair Powell
5. Trump on April 21st: Fed Chair Powell is "a major loser"
6. Trump today: "No intention" to fire Fed Chair Powell
What changed today?

item.title:
BREAKING: Foreign investors pulled ~$5 billion out of US corporate bond funds over the last 2 weeks, the most since April 2020.
As a result, the 4-week moving average jumped to ~$1.2 billion, the highest since the 2020 pandemic.
During this time, the high-yield corporate bond ETF, $HYG, and the investment-grade corporate bond ETF, $LQD, have fallen by -1.2% and -0.9%, respectively.
Meanwhile, high-yield corporate bond spreads have risen 1.5 percentage points over the last 2 months, to 4.16%, near the highest in 2 years.
However, foreign investors still own ~$4.4 trillion, or 27%, of the total US corporate bond market, according to BofA.
Will foreigners continue dumping US¬†assets? (From TKL)
item.content:
BREAKING: Foreign investors pulled ~$5 billion out of US corporate bond funds over the last 2 weeks, the most since April 2020.

As a result, the 4-week moving average jumped to ~$1.2 billion, the highest since the 2020 pandemic.

During this time, the high-yield corporate bond ETF, $HYG, and the investment-grade corporate bond ETF, $LQD, have fallen by -1.2% and -0.9%, respectively.

Meanwhile, high-yield corporate bond spreads have risen 1.5 percentage points over the last 2 months, to 4.16%, near the highest in 2 years.

However, foreign investors still own ~$4.4 trillion, or 27%, of the total US corporate bond market, according to BofA.

Will foreigners continue dumping US¬†assets?
item.contentSnippet:
BREAKING: Foreign investors pulled ~$5 billion out of US corporate bond funds over the last 2 weeks, the most since April 2020. $HYG, and the investment-grade corporate bond ETF, $LQD, have fallen by -1.2% and -0.9%, respectively.
Meanwhile, high-yield corporate bond spreads have risen 1.5 percentage points over the last 2 months, to 4.16%, near the highest in 2 years.
However, foreign investors still own ~$4.4 trillion, or 27%, of the total US corporate bond market, according to BofA.
Will foreigners continue dumping US¬†assets?

item.title:
Another recession signal has arrived:
The copper-to-gold ratio has dropped to its lowest level in at least 40 years.
This ratio has halved over the last 3 years.
The decline has accelerated over the last month as gold prices have risen +9% while copper prices have plummeted -8%.
A rapidly falling copper-to-gold ratio has historically signaled weakening global economic activity.
Previous major downturns in this indicator were seen during 2020 and 2008.
Are we already in a recession? (From TKL)
item.content:
Another recession signal has arrived:

The copper-to-gold ratio has dropped to its lowest level in at least 40 years.

This ratio has halved over the last 3 years.

The decline has accelerated over the last month as gold prices have risen +9% while copper prices have plummeted -8%.

A rapidly falling copper-to-gold ratio has historically signaled weakening global economic activity.

Previous major downturns in this indicator were seen during 2020 and 2008.

Are we already in a recession?
item.contentSnippet:

The copper-to-gold ratio has dropped to its lowest level in at least 40 years.
This ratio has halved over the last 3 years.
The decline has accelerated over the last month as gold prices have risen +9% while copper prices have plummeted -8%.
A rapidly falling copper-to-gold ratio has historically signaled weakening global economic activity.
Previous major downturns in this indicator were seen during 2020 and 2008.

item.title:
Typical home (condo/co-op) value in Manhattan today is $1.1 million.
Typical apartment rent is $5,091/month, or $61,000 per year.
The resulting home value/rent ratio in Manhattan is 18.5, the lowest it's been in 20+ years.
Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:

Indicating Manhattan might actually be a good place to buy right now.

RT by @SchwabResearch: Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:

‚Äî¬†Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession. (From SchwabR)
item.content:
Today on The Big Picture on Market On Close:

‚Äî¬†@LizAnnSonders says that "any move by the Fed to preemptively start easing policy aggressively ... might not have the intended effect of boosting growth or boosting confidence."

‚Äî¬†Cooper Howard tells @Cline_Woods that "the market is concerned about the independence of the Fed."

‚Äî¬†Plus, tracking the likelihood of a recession.

item.title: RT by @Barchart: NEWSLETTER: Something very weird is happening. (From Barchart)

item.title:
#Earnings get heavy this week. With 12% of S&P 500 companies reporting results, 71% have beaten analysts' earnings per share estimates and 61% have reported a positive revenue surprise. Economic reports include March new home sales, the Fed's Beige Book on economic conditions around the country, and final April consumer sentiment.
For more on the week ahead: üì∞ Read the latest Schwab Market Update ‚û°Ô∏èhttps://www.schwab.com/learn/story/stock-market-update-open
üé• Watch @JeffreyKleintop 90-second Weekly Market Outlook video ‚§µÔ∏è (From SchwabR)

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 7) In the meantime, Reventure still expects prices to drop. We have Austin tabbed as a 32/100 on our price forecast score, which corresponds to -6.3% contraction over next 12 months.
To access our price forecast for your area, head to http://www.reventure.app and sign up for a premium plan. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
7) In the meantime, Reventure still expects prices to drop. We have Austin tabbed as a 32/100 on our price forecast score, which corresponds to -6.3% contraction over next 12 months.

To access our price forecast for your area, head to reventure.app and sign up for a premium plan.
item.contentSnippet: 7) In the meantime, Reventure still expects prices to drop. We have Austin tabbed as a 32/100 on our price forecast score, which corresponds to -6.3% contraction over next 12 months. reventure.app and sign up for a premium plan.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end.
item.contentSnippet: 6) I will be likely buying real estate in Austin by the end of this year, as I feel confident this market has good long-term prospects and will have the right affordability and valuation metrics by year-end.

item.title: R to @nickgerli1: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic). (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic).
item.contentSnippet: 5) But I think the fundamentals of Austin are solid. The area's population growth is top of the table. And now prices/rents are cheap enough to allow that growth to continue into the future (after a brief hangover after the pandemic).

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 4) Austin's rental market suggests prices are a bit more overvalued.
The Home Price / Rent Ratio is currently 17.6.
While the long-run average is 15.2. Suggesting 15% overvaluation. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
4) Austin's rental market suggests prices are a bit more overvalued.

The Home Price / Rent Ratio is currently 17.6.

While the long-run average is 15.2. Suggesting 15% overvaluation.
item.contentSnippet:
4) Austin's rental market suggests prices are a bit more overvalued.
The Home Price / Rent Ratio is currently 17.6.
While the long-run average is 15.2. Suggesting 15% overvaluation.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 3) Prior to pandemic, in 2019, prices in Austin traded for 4.0x income.
The typical value was $313k and the median income was $78k.
In order to understand home prices, you have to understand it's all relative. Income is the main input that matters, along with rent. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
3) Prior to pandemic, in 2019, prices in Austin traded for 4.0x income.

The typical value was $313k and the median income was $78k.

In order to understand home prices, you have to understand it's all relative. Income is the main input that matters, along with rent.
item.contentSnippet:
3) Prior to pandemic, in 2019, prices in Austin traded for 4.0x income.
The typical value was $313k and the median income was $78k.
In order to understand home prices, you have to understand it's all relative. Income is the main input that matters, along with rent.

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 2) To understand this point clearer: the typical home value in Austin is $449k right now. Which is 4.4x the area's median income.
This 4.4x Home Value/Income Ratio is now almost back down to the long-term, 20 -year average.
Which is how you know Austin will soon be a "buy". (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
2) To understand this point clearer: the typical home value in Austin is $449k right now. Which is 4.4x the area's median income.

This 4.4x Home Value/Income Ratio is now almost back down to the long-term, 20 -year average.

Which is how you know Austin will soon be a "buy".
item.contentSnippet:
2) To understand this point clearer: the typical home value in Austin is $449k right now. Which is 4.4x the area's median income.
This 4.4x Home Value/Income Ratio is now almost back down to the long-term, 20 -year average.
Which is how you know Austin will soon be a "buy".

item.title:
R to @nickgerli1: 1) The way Austin has become more fairly valued is through two mechanisms.
First - prices have dropped 20.4% from their peak in 2022. Returning affordability.
Second - the median income in the metro has continued rising, and is now up to $102,000, increasing relative affordability. (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
1) The way Austin has become more fairly valued is through two mechanisms.

First - prices have dropped 20.4% from their peak in 2022. Returning affordability.

Second - the median income in the metro has continued rising, and is now up to $102,000, increasing relative affordability.
item.contentSnippet:
1) The way Austin has become more fairly valued is through two mechanisms.
First - prices have dropped 20.4% from their peak in 2022. Returning affordability.
Second - the median income in the metro has continued rising, and is now up to $102,000, increasing relative affordability.

item.title:
The first market to bottom in this housing downturn will be Austin, TX.
Prices are already down 20% from peak.
And the market has shifted from being 46% overvalued to now only 8% overvalued.
Buy the end of this year, Austin will be a "buy". (From Nick Gerli_Realestate)
item.content:
The first market to bottom in this housing downturn will be Austin, TX.

Prices are already down 20% from peak.

And the market has shifted from being 46% overvalued to now only 8% overvalued.

Buy the end of this year, Austin will be a "buy".
item.contentSnippet:
The first market to bottom in this housing downturn will be Austin, TX.
Prices are already down 20% from peak.
And the market has shifted from being 46% overvalued to now only 8% overvalued.
Buy the end of this year, Austin will be a "buy".
